Award.AwardTitle: International Research Fellowship Program: Evolution of Nickel Hyper-accumulation in the Plant genus Stackhousia
Award.AbstractNarration:
0965674
Burge


The International Research Fellowship Program enables U.S. scientists and engineers to conduct nine to twenty-four months of research abroad. The program's awards provide opportunities for joint research, and the use of unique or complementary facilities, expertise and experimental conditions abroad.

This award will support a twenty-four-month research fellowship by Dr. Dylan Burge to work with Dr. Balwant Singh at the University of Sydney in Australia, with Dr. Maurizio Rossetto at the Royal Botanic Gardens in Sydney, with Dr. Bill Barker at the State Herbarium of South Australia and with Dr. Loren Rieseberg at Indiana University in the US.

Beginning with the origin of life itself, evolution has been characterized by adaptation to extreme environments. To gain understanding of organismal diversity and anticipate the response of living things to predicted perturbations in the global environment such as global warming, it is important to study extremes of adaptation. More than 320 species of flowering plants accumulate the element nickel in their tissues to levels exceeding 0.1%, concentrations that would be toxic to most organisms. This phenomenon, known as nickel hyper-accumulation, represents a unique adaptation to soils that are rich in nickel. Nickel hyper-accumulation is thought to have evolved independently in several plant lineages. Recent research has focused on ecology, genetics, and physiology of nickel hyper-accumulation, work that is motivated in part by the potential use of these plants for detoxification of nickel contaminated soils. In spite of this great interest, little is known about evolution of nickel hyper-accumulation in specific plant groups, hindering research on the evolution of this intriguing and extreme plant adaptation. This project will combine methods from soil science, ecology, population genetics, and genomics in a synergistic approach designed to elucidate how nickel hyper-accumulation has evolved in the Australian plant genus Stackhousia. The research will also develop Stackhousia as a model system for research on the evolution and genetics of Ni hyper-accumulation. Furthermore, the approach developed here will be applicable to other plant groups containing Ni hyper-accumulating species, leading to greater insight into the evolution of this intriguing trait, which appears to have developed independently at least 15 times during the diversification of flowering plants.

POR.DRECONTENT:
My research under the auspices of the International Research Fellowship Program (IRFP) sought to understand the genetic basis of an unusual, poorly understood, and potentially economically valuable plant trait—metal hyperaccumulation. Hyperaccumulating plant species are able to absorb and store heavy metals—such as nickel, copper, and chromium—at greater than 1% of their dry mass. However, the genes that underlie this trait, and the way in which it evolves, were unknown at the beginning of my research project. In my research, I sought to uncover the genetic basis of nickel hyperaccumulation using a group of herbaceous plants endemic to Australia and New Zealand, the genus Stackhousia. This genus is made up of about 50 species, only one of which was thought the be capable of nickel hyperaccumulation. Using a suite of tools from the arsenal of several disparate research fields, including geology, soil science, ecology, evolution, and genomics, I was able to determine how the trait evolved during the diversification of Stackhousia, and uncover the genetic basis of the trait. Evolutionary trees for the group, combined with results from greenhouse experiments, indicate that nickel tolerance, and the capacity for nickel accumulation, varies greatly across Stackhousia, with some capacity for unusual levels of accumulation present in most of the major groups of species. This finding suggests that the ability to accumulate nickel may be latent in all of Stackhousia, and that hyperaccumulation could have evolved from this variation. Further research, using a technique called RNA sequencing, revealed the genes at work in nickel accumulation in Stackhousia. These genes are primarily involved in metal transport across the cell membrane. These results have implications for future research on the evolution of metal hyperaccumulation.

My research into the evolution and genetic basis of nickel hyperaccumulation has a variety of impacts, from potential industrial applications to outreach. The discovery of several genes involved in nickel hyperaccumulation has potential applications in phytomining, an approach to mining in which plants are used to extract valuable metals from the earth. Such work could help to reduce the societal and environmental impacts of mining, including cleanup of contaminated mines. Throughout the course of my project, I also created products for dissemination to the general public, including a research website (ww.edaphics.com), YouTube videos demonstrating aspects of the research, including a series of videos that demonstrate, using real plants, how “mining with plants” is possible (www.youtube.com/user/dylanburgevideo) and regular blog posts (www.edaphics.blogspot.com) featuring aspects of my research. In addition, I recruited and trained a female undergraduate student from the United States to help with this project. This assistant participated in the planning and execution of all aspects of the research, and has subsequently acquired a position in a research laboratory at the University of Georgia, where she works in a similar capacity as she did on my project.
